div.p: From Stanley Dobson to Ebenezer Thomas
A84/8354, unit 59, VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.

In answer to your letter of yesterdays date
Letter not found. See, however, S. Dobson to J. Service, 12 September 1884 (in this edition as M84-09-12). and the question therein contained I beg to say that the proposed Botanical Key would stimulate the study of the Science both in the State Schools and amongst the public at large. If Mr Service has any doubts as to the value of such a work I will be happy to wait on him and in a quarter of an hour I will explain the system and probably teach him more Botany than he has yet learned. My great hope is that the Teachers in the up-country schools may be induced to take kindly to the book and thus give to the children some intelligent employment for their leisure hours — even whilst they are walking to & from School. It was with this view that some months ago I wrote to the Minister of Public Instruction urging him to defray costs of the publication from his vote, but the answer was that such a work was not within the scope of his department. I know of many cases of quite young children working with "Spicers" Key in Tasmania
Spicer (1878). See also, in the same file, S. Dobson to J. Servioce, 19 September 1884.
